title:
Lie bialgebra structures on the Lie algebra
  $\widetilde{\frak{sl}_2(C_q[x,y])}$

title_detail.value:
Lie bialgebra structures on the Lie algebra
  $\widetilde{\frak{sl}_2(C_q[x,y])}$

summary:
In the present paper we shall investigate the Lie bialgebra structures on the
Lie algebra $\widetilde{\frak{sl}_2(C_q[x,y])}$, which are shown to be
triangular coboundary.

summary_detail.value:
In the present paper we shall investigate the Lie bialgebra structures on the
Lie algebra $\widetilde{\frak{sl}_2(C_q[x,y])}$, which are shown to be
triangular coboundary.

author: Wei Wang
fulltext:
^
Lie bialgebra structures on the Lie algebra sl2 (C
q [x, y])
Ying Xu1) , Junbo Li2) , Wei Wang3)
1) Wu

arXiv:1102.5613v2 [math.QA] 26 Oct 2012

Wen-Tsun Key Laboratory of Mathematics,
University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China
2) School of Mathematics and Statistics, Changshu Institute of Technology, Changshu 215500, China
3) School of Mathematics and Computer Science, Ningxia University, Yinchuan 750021, China
Abstract. In the present paper we shall investigate the Lie bialgebra structures on the Lie algebra
^
sl2 (C
q [x, y]), which are shown to be triangular coboundary.
^
Key words: Lie bialgebras, Yang-Baxter equation, Lie algebra sl2 (C
q [x, y]).
Mathematics Subject Classification (2000): 17B05, 17B37, 17B62, 17B67.

§1. Introduction
In order to find more about the solutions of the Yang-Baxter quantum equations, Drinfeld
firstly introduced the notion of Lie bialgebras in 1983 (see [4]). Since then this issue has
caused wide public concern (see [5], [6], [13]). Witt and Virasoro type Lie bialgebras were
introduced in [16], which were further classified in [14]. The generalized case was considered
in [15]. Lie bialgebra structures on generalized Virasoro-like and Block Lie algebras were
investigated in [18] and [10] respectively. The same problem on the q-analog Virasoro-like
algebra was settled in [3]. In the paper we shall concentrate on this problem on a more
^
completed Lie algebra sl2 (C
q [x, y]), which is closely related to the q-analog Virasoro-like
algebra.
Fix a nonzero complex number q which is not a root of unity. Let Cq be the C-algebra
Cq [x, y] defined by generators x, y and relations yx = qxy. Firstly, we introduce the Lie
algebra L = sl2 (Cq [x, y]). Set 0 = (0, 0). For k = (k1 , k2 ) ∈ Z2≥0 , m = (m1 , m2 ) ∈ Z2≥0 \{0}
and i = 1, 2, define the following elements of L
ek = E12 xk1 y k2 ,

fk = E21 xk1 y k2 ,

h = E11 − E22 ,

ǫi (m) = Eii xm1 y m2 ,

which form a basis of L and satisfy the following brackets
[ǫ1 (k), fm ] = −q k1 m2 fk+m ,

[ǫ2 (k), fm ] = q k2 m1 fk+m ,

[ǫ1 (k), em ] = q k2 m1 ek+m ,

[ǫ2 (k), em ] = −q k1 m2 ek+m ,

[ek , fm ] = q k2 m1 ǫ1 (k + m) − q m2 k1 ǫ2 (k + m),
[ǫi (k), ǫj (m)] = δij (q k2 m1 − q m2 k1 )ǫi (k + m),
[ek , em ] = [fk , fm ] = [h, ǫi (m)] = 0, [h, ek ] = 2ek , [h, fk ] = −2fk .
Supported by NSF grants (No 10825101, 11101056) and the China Postdoctoral Science Foundation Grant
(No 201003326)

1

 This Lie algebra appeared during the study of some extended affine Lie algebras in [1] and
while taking q = 1 limit of the quantum toroidal algebras in [17]. Representation and central
extensions of the loop algebra with the algebra of Laurent polynomials replaced by a quantum
torus [12] attract a great many specialists and scholars (see [9], [11], [2], [7] and [8]). In this
^
paper, we investigate the Lie bialgebra structures on sl2 (C
q [x, y]) with replacing Laurent
polynomials by polynomials.
For convenience we introduce the following notations
Ek1 ,k2 = ek ,

Fk1 ,k2 = fk ,

Gm1 ,m2 = ǫ1 (m),

Hm1 ,m2 = ǫ2 (m),

D = h.

Then the relations can be rewritten as follows under the new basis notations
[Ek1 ,k2 , El1 ,l2 ] = [Fk1 ,k2 , Fl1 ,l2 ] = 0,

[Gm1 ,m2 , Hn1 ,n2 ] = 0,

[D, Ek1 ,k2 ] = 2Ek1 ,k2 , [D, Fk1,k2 ] = −2Fk1 ,k2 , [D, Gm1 ,m2 ] = [D, Hm1 ,m2 ] = 0,
[Gm1 ,m2 , Fk1 ,k2 ] = −q m1 k2 Fm1 +k1 ,m2 +k2 ,

[Hm1 ,m2 , Fk1 ,k2 ] = q m2 k1 Fm1 +k1 ,m2 +k2 ,

[Gm1 ,m2 , Ek1 ,k2 ] = q m2 k1 Em1 +k1 ,m2 +k2 ,

[Hm1 ,m2 , Ek1 ,k2 ] = −q m1 k2 Em1 +k1 ,m2 +k2 ,

[Gm1 ,m2 , Gn1 ,n2 ] = (q m2 n1 − q n2 m1 )Gm1 +n1 ,m2 +n2 ,
[Hm1 ,m2 , Hn1 ,n2 ] = (q m2 n1 − q n2 m1 )Hm1 +n1 ,m2 +n2 ,
( kl

q k2 l1 D

[D1 , D2 ] = [Di , D] = 0,
[Di , x] = ki x for x ∈ Lk1 ,k2 , i = 1, 2.
Then we arrive at the Lie algebra Le = L ⊕ CD1 ⊕ CD2 which we shall consider in this paper.
It is easy to see that Le possesses the following triangular decomposition: Le = Le− ⊕ H ⊕ Le+

2

 Recall the relevant knowledge on Lie bialgebras, which could be found in [10] or [18]. For
any C-vector space L, denote ξ the cyclic map of L⊗L⊗L with ξ(x1 ⊗x2 ⊗x3 ) = x2 ⊗x3 ⊗x1
and τ the twist map of L ⊗ L with τ (x1 ⊗ x2 ) = x2 ⊗ x1 for any x1 , x2 , x3 ∈ L. A Lie algebra
is a pair (L, δ) of a vector space L and a linear map δ : L ⊗ L → L (the bracket) admitting
Ker(1 − τ ) ⊂ Ker δ,

δ * (1 ⊗ δ) * (1 + ξ + ξ 2 ) = 0.

A Lie coalgebra is a pair (L, ∆) of a vector space L and a linear map ∆ : L → L ⊗ L (the
cobracket) admitting
Im ∆ ⊂ Im(1 − τ ),

(1 + ξ + ξ 2 ) * (1 ⊗ ∆) * ∆ = 0.

(1.1)

For a Lie algebra L, we always use the symbol "*" to stand for the diagonal adjoint action
x*(

i

Definition 1.1 A Lie bialgebra is a triple (L, δ, ∆) admitting the following conditions
(L, δ) is a Lie algebra, (L, ∆) is a Lie coalgebra,
∆δ(x, y) = x * ∆y − y * ∆x, ∀ x, y ∈ L (the compatibility condition).

(1.2)

Denote by U the universal enveloping algebra of L and by 1 the identity element of U.

i

Definition 1.2 (1) A coboundary Lie bialgebra is a 4-tuple (L, δ, ∆, r), where (L, δ, ∆) is a
Lie bialgebra and r ∈ Im(1 − τ ) ⊂ L ⊗ L such that ∆ = ∆r is a coboundary of r, where ∆r
is defined by
∆r (x) = x * r for x ∈ L.

(1.3)

(2) A coboundary Lie bialgebra (L, δ, ∆, r) is called triangular if it satisfies the following
classical Yang-Baxter Equation
c(r) = 0.
The main result of this paper can be formulated as follows.
Theorem 1.3 Every Lie bialgebra on Le is triangular coboundary.
3

(1.4)

 §2. Proof of the main result
The following lemma can be found in [4] or [14].
Lemma 2.1 Let L be a Lie algebra and r ∈ Im(1 − τ ) ⊂ L ⊗ L.
(1) The tripple (L, [*, *], ∆r ) is a Lie bialgebra if and only if r satisfies (1.4).
(2) For any x ∈ L,
(1 + ξ + ξ 2 ) * (1 ⊗ ∆) * ∆(x) = x * c(r).

Proof. Denote Γ = {(k1 , k2) | ki ∈ Z, i = 1, 2} and T = SpanC {D1 , D2 }. Define the nondegenerate bilinear map form C2 × T −→ C, ρ(c) = (c, ρ) = c1 ρ1 + c2 ρ2 , for c = (c1 , c2 ) ∈ C2 ,

The proof of this claim will be done by several Subclaims.

Subclaim 1 By replacing D0 by D0 − uinn for some u ∈ V0 , one can suppose D0 (Le0 ) = 0.

Proof. It is well known that the first cohomology group of sl2 (C) vanishes on finite dimensional modules. And the subalgebra {E0 , F0 , D} can be regarded as the Lie algebra sl2 (C).
Then the subclaim follows from a very simple computation which shall be omitted here. 

 e Then v ∈ Im(1 − τ ).
Lemma 2.5 Suppose v ∈ V such that x * v ∈ Im(1 − τ ) for all x ∈ L.

Proof. It is easy to see that Im(1 − τ ) = ker(1 + τ ). Then for any v ∈ V such that
Le * v ∈ Im(1 − τ ), one has (1 + τ )(Le * v) = 0. Noting that τ commutes with the action of
Le on V, we obtain Le * (1 + τ )v = (1 + τ )(Le * v) = 0, which together with Lemma 2.2, forces

(1 + τ )v = 0. Then this lemma follows from the fact that Ker(1 + τ ) = Im(1 − τ ).
